--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin
> <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> > I'm making real progress on the concentration
> evolver.
> >  It now evolves ANNs that are much better than a
> > random player!  This game requires active use of
> > memory during the game.  All of the previous ANNs
> that
> 
> Very interesting work!  So how many generations is
> it
> taking?  Is it approaching perfect play or does it
> stagnate?
> It would be great to have a perfect concentration
> player
> in a net like this.

These are very preliminary results.  The results I
reported were against a totally random opponent.  It
takes a few hundred generations to become clearly
better.  With a population of 200 it was taking
about11 seconds per generation.  I have no idea how
close it is to being a perfect player; I would guess
not so close.  The average winning percentage of the
population was about 80% when it always has the first
move.

I just this evening got the dual population running. 
They appear to be evolving against each other, but I
have no way of know how good they are!  The
first-movers are winning about 60% of the games and
the 2nd movers about 40%.  They might all be playing
near-perfect games or all just about like random
players.

That is an unforeseen problem with co-evolution; you
can't easily tell how they are doing if the evolve
together.  I need to add some objective measure
because I like to know what's happening.  I won't use
that for evolution, just for observation.
